Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Patterned Microtexture to Create Fluid Film Lubrication at Low Sliding Velocities in Prosthetic Knee Joints

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grant in Engineering (BRIGE) grant provides funding for the design of prosthetic knee implant bearing surfaces with a patterned microtexture. The primary goal of this research is to extend implant durability compared to state-of-the-art smooth implants by creating hydrodynamic lubrication at low joint sliding velocities to reduce friction and wear. A model of the sliding components of a prosthetic knee joint with patterned microtexture will be implemented using a finite difference formulation. The defining parameters of the microtexture will be optimized to maximize the bearing load carrying capacity and the separation between the bearing surfaces. The model will account for the non-Newtonian nature of the lubricant (synovial fluid) and the variable spacing between the bearing surfaces during gait. Laser surface texturing will be used to fabricate the patterned microtexture. A prototype prosthetic knee implant with an optimized, patterned microtexture design will be built to validate the model and experimentally compare friction and wear of microtextured and smooth prosthetic knee bearing surfaces.

This study will provide critical insight on the effect of microtexture for the transition from boundary lubrication to hydrodynamic lubrication at low, variable sliding velocities in the presence of a non-Newtonian lubricant. Specifically, the results of this research will contribute to improving the durability of bearing surfaces of prosthetic knee implants by drastically reducing friction and wear. This could mark the beginning of a new generation of prosthetic implants with much improved durability, to serve an aging population and reduce health care costs. By extension, this research will also apply to reducing friction and wear in other implants, such as hip and shoulder implants. During this project, participation of students from underrepresented groups will be promoted through K-12 outreach and undergraduate research. An interactive module and curriculum related to friction will be contributed to the annual Hi-GEAR camp at the University of Utah for female high school students. Additionally, a demo-kit will be part of the Discover Engineering Display, which visits high schools in the Salt Lake City metro area.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Approximately 650,000 total knee replacement surgeries are performed in the United States each year. Most prosthetic knee joints consist of a cobalt-chromium (CoCr) femoral component that articulates with a polyethylene tibial insert, lubricated with joint fluid. The statistical survivorship of these prosthetic knee joints declines significantly after 15 years of use, primarily due to wear and wear debris incited disease. The current engineering paradigm has focused on increasing the longevity of prosthetic knee joints by improving the mechanical properties of the polyethylene component, or by manufacturing ultra-smooth articulating surfaces. In contrast, this project has focused on increasing the longevity of prosthetic knee joints by adding a patterned microtexture to the ultra-smooth CoCr femoral component. The patterned microtexture increases the lubricant film thickness between the articulating surfaces, thereby reducing friction and wear.

Specifically, this research has addressed the problem of reducing friction by creating elastohydrodynamic lubrication between reciprocating sliding surfaces at low sliding velocities using a patterned surface microtexture on one of the surfaces. We have implemented and validated an elastohydrodynamic lubrication model of a portion of the prosthetic knee joint. The model includes microtexture and accurate mechanical properties of both the femoral component, tibial insert, and lubricant. Using this model, we have optimized the surface microtexture geometry to maximize the lubricant film thickness between the reciprocating sliding surfaces. In addition, we have modeled the effect of surface roughness in the microtexture features on the bearing performance, and found that the magnitude and topography of the roughness may play a role in the bearing performance. Hence, we have used this information to optimize the microtexture manufacturing process. We have experimentally demonstrated that an optimized microtexture geometry reduces friction in a surrogate prosthetic knee bearing compared to a conventional smooth (untextured bearing). We have demonstrated this for different microtexture designs, and different contact geometries including convex cylinder (CoCr) on flat polyethylene and convex cylinder on concave polyethylene. The real prosthetic knee contact geometry is somewhere in between these two extreme cases, and is dependent on the type of prosthetic knee and the manufacturer of the device.

The results obtained in the experimental and modeling portions of the project have been published in conference and journal publications. Furthermore, the results of this research will be translated to designing bearing surfaces of prosthetic joints with drastically reduced friction and unprecedented durability and survival rates, and mark the beginning of a new generation of prosthetic joints to serve an aging population and reduce health care costs.

To encourage broader participating of underrepresented groups in engineering, we have organized an annual tribology workshop for female high-school students who take part in the University of Utah HI-GEAR camp. We have surveyed all participants after the workshop to obtain feedback and received a positive evaluation from the students. Most of the students reported never having thought about friction and wear before this workshop, but enjoying the insights gained. It is too early to report conversion rates showing that students who participated in the HI-GEAR camp also enrolled in an engineering major in college. However, historically, the HI-GEAR camp has shown tremendous success, with conversion rates in excess of 60%.

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2016
Modified by: Bart Raeymaekers

Most prosthetic knee joints consist of a cobalt-chromium (CoCr) femoral component that articulates with a polyethylene tibial insert, lubricated with joint fluid. The statistical survivorship of these prosthetic knee joints declines significantly after 15 years of use, primarily due to wear and wear debris incited disease. It is too early to report conversion rates showing that students who participated in the HI-GEAR camp also enrolled in an engineering major in college.
